Award.AwardTitle: SaTC-EDU:EAGER:A Wiki Space for Information Security Education Exchange

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Information security remains a persistent and growing problem in the United States due to ever-progressing reliance on information technologies and systems to provide critical services and enable society's contemporary way of life. The economics of computing favor performance and functionality over security and may continue to do so for some time. This environment is created by graduates of education programs, programs which can be argued to be lacking in emphasis on security impacts associated with this new information age. The economics of education are also pitted against cyber security education. Cyber security education is a resource intensive endeavor that requires program refreshes on a regular basis as technology changes and advances. The level of expertise necessary to provide continual curricula development is also a barrier, which reduces the number of institutions that are able to effectively keep up with the advancement of technology.

The purpose of this project is to create a sharing community of educators from institutions in the Center of Academic Excellence (CAE) program for Information Assurance and those wishing to develop better educational resources for their programs. This community will be reinforced with an online wiki maintained by the community. The mediated wiki platform will assist in the mapping of resources and tools to the Knowledge Unit (KU) system emplaced to cover the required learning areas in cybersecurity. This wiki will allow sharing of educational materials, including texts, labs, tools, and exams. This project will reduce the level of work required from educators to build and retool classes to the rapidly evolving field of cybersecurity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SaTC-EDU:EAGER:A Wiki Space for Information Security Education Exchange

The investigators conceived of an idea for an adaptive mechanism to collect and disseminate cybersecurity educational guidelines produced by agencies of the US due to their continuing evolution. Because the nation’s critical information resources continue to change significantly due to rapid technical innovation, the means by which they are secured changes as well. Our primary focus was in assembling guidelines from the National Security Agency in the form of Knowledge Units (KUs) that are prone to revision over time. In addition, while the government provides guideline information in the form of KUs, it does not offer the means to map instructional plans and exercises created by cybersecurity educators.

For these reasons, we embarked on the project to create a wiki environment, employing the same software as the Wikipedia online encyclopedia to create CyberEd Wiki (https://cyberedwiki.org/). CyberEd Wiki allows the investigators to combine government-produce guidance with the contributions of cybersecurity editors to the wiki to facilitate the establishment and modification of cybersecurity curricula in a collaborative environment. Dozens of cybersecurity educators at institutions from two-year colleges to research universities have employed the site or made contributions to it.

There were unforeseen issues in establishing CyberEd Wiki, primarily due to issues in the MediaWiki software employed on the project. These technical issues have been resolved, although with revisions of the software, new issues will doubtlessly arrive. Our next major objective is to expand the base of contributors to the platform while adding additional cybersecurity knowledge areas from sources both within and outside the US government. The investigators hold resources sufficient to continue to grow and maintain the CyberEd Wiki platform for the next several years and will work the NSA and National Institute for Standards and Technology on incorporating new and revised cybersecurity education information.
